interventions.name: Night Guard
interventions.description: A dental appliance worn at night to protect teeth from grinding damage and reduce jaw muscle activity.
interventions.detailedDescription: Custom-fitted hard acrylic splints are recommended over soft or OTC options. While they don't reduce grinding frequency, they effectively prevent expensive dental damage. A properly fitted night guard should last 2-5 years with regular care.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Cochrane review (2007) finds insufficient evidence that splints reduce grinding, but moderate evidence they protect teeth from damage. No updated Cochrane review since.

interventions.name: Botox Injections
interventions.description: Botulinum toxin injections into the masseter muscles to reduce grinding force. Requires professional administration.
interventions.detailedDescription: Meta-analyses show Botox significantly reduces pain (~4 points on 10-point VAS scale), bite force, and bruxism events (from ~5 to ~1.7 episodes/hour). Effects last 3-6 months. Long-term use may cause bone density concerns in the jaw. Reserve for severe or refractory cases.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Meta-analyses show significant pain reduction and decreased bruxism events. Cost and bone density concerns limit long-term use.

interventions.name: Charge Biofeedback Device
interventions.description: Remember to charge your Muse headband so it's ready for tonight's sleep session.
interventions.detailedDescription: Small studies suggest EMG-based biofeedback may reduce clenching episodes in the short term, though effects can diminish after several weeks due to habituation. Keeping your device charged ensures you don't miss a night of monitoring. The Muse headband typically needs charging every 2-3 days with regular overnight use.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Small studies show short-term reductions in EMG activity; long-term evidence is limited due to habituation effects after ~4 weeks.

interventions.name: Sleep Apnea Treatment
interventions.description: CPAP or mandibular advancement devices for patients with obstructive sleep apnea, a common bruxism comorbidity.
interventions.detailedDescription: Multiple RCTs show both CPAP and MADs significantly reduce bruxism in patients with confirmed OSA. If you snore, experience daytime fatigue, or have witnessed apneas, consider a sleep study. Treating the underlying sleep disorder often resolves the bruxism.
interventions.evidenceSummary: RCTs show significant bruxism reduction when underlying OSA is treated with CPAP or mandibular advancement devices.

interventions.name: SSRI Medication Review
interventions.description: Review of SSRI medications if bruxism started after beginning antidepressants. Buspirone may help.
interventions.detailedDescription: In reported cases of antidepressant-induced bruxism, SSRIs account for about 74% (actual risk for SSRI users is ~24% vs 15% baseline). If grinding started after beginning an SSRI, discuss with your doctor‚Äînever stop SSRIs abruptly. Consider using a dental guard while awaiting improvement. Adding buspirone (5-30mg) may help but takes 2-3 weeks to work; buspirone is contraindicated with MAO inhibitors and liver disease.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Systematic review confirms SSRI-bruxism link (~24% vs 15% baseline risk). Case series show buspirone may help; improvement takes 2-3 weeks.

interventions.name: Tongue Posture
interventions.description: Keep tongue resting on the roof of mouth with teeth slightly apart. This position makes clenching difficult.
interventions.detailedDescription: The 'lips together, teeth apart, tongue on palate' position physically prevents clenching. Set hourly reminders during the day to check and reset your jaw position. This is most effective for awake bruxism but builds awareness that may carry into sleep.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Clinical experience supports jaw positioning. Most effective for awake bruxism; limited evidence for sleep bruxism reduction.

interventions.name: Jaw Relaxation
interventions.description: Practice letting your jaw hang loose with lips closed. Notice and release tension throughout the day.
interventions.detailedDescription: Progressive muscle relaxation specifically targeting the jaw muscles. Notice when you're clenching during stress and consciously release. Combine with deep breathing for better results.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Part of behavioral approaches shown to help with awake bruxism. Limited direct evidence for sleep bruxism.

interventions.name: Stress Reduction
interventions.description: Meditation, deep breathing, or other stress management techniques. Stress is a major trigger for bruxism.
interventions.detailedDescription: Stress is consistently associated with increased bruxism. Regular meditation, deep breathing, yoga, or other stress management techniques can help. Even 10 minutes daily may make a difference.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Strong association between stress and bruxism. Stress reduction improves symptoms though direct RCT evidence is limited.

interventions.name: Jaw Massage
interventions.description: Gentle massage of the masseter and temporalis muscles to relieve tension and improve circulation.
interventions.detailedDescription: RCTs show deep-stripping massage improves sleep quality, jaw mobility, and pain pressure threshold. Self-massage of the masseter (cheek) and temporalis (temple) muscles for 5 minutes twice daily is free and effective.
interventions.evidenceSummary: RCT evidence shows massage improves sleep quality and jaw mobility. Self-massage is free and low-risk.

interventions.name: Avoid Caffeine
interventions.description: Avoid caffeine, especially after noon. High caffeine is associated with increased bruxism.
interventions.detailedDescription: Systematic review shows high caffeine consumption (>8 cups/day) increases bruxism odds by ~1.5x. Cut off caffeine by noon and limit to 2-3 cups daily. This includes coffee, tea, energy drinks, and chocolate. Check this off at the end of the day if you successfully avoided caffeine.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Systematic review confirms caffeine-bruxism association. Reducing intake has additional sleep quality benefits.

interventions.name: Avoid Alcohol
interventions.description: Avoid alcohol, which doubles the odds of sleep bruxism.
interventions.detailedDescription: Systematic review shows alcohol consumption increases bruxism odds by approximately 2x. Avoid alcohol within 4 hours of bedtime. The sleep disruption from alcohol also indirectly worsens bruxism. Check this off at the end of the day if you successfully avoided alcohol.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Systematic review shows ~2x odds increase for bruxism with alcohol use. Easy lifestyle modification.

interventions.name: Jaw Exercises
interventions.description: Specific stretching and strengthening exercises for the jaw muscles. Best done multiple times daily.
interventions.detailedDescription: The Rocabado 6x6 exercises are commonly prescribed by physical therapists. Includes jaw stretches, posture correction, and muscle relaxation. Initial PT guidance is valuable, then continue at home for free.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Improves pain and mouth opening but does not directly reduce grinding activity. Helpful for symptom management.

interventions.name: GERD Treatment
interventions.description: Managing gastroesophageal reflux disease, which is strongly associated with sleep bruxism.
interventions.detailedDescription: A case-control study found OR=6.87 for GERD-bruxism association (note: limited independent replication; anxiety/depression may partially mediate this link). If you have acid reflux symptoms, treating the GERD with PPIs or lifestyle changes may help. One small RCT showed rabeprazole reduced rhythmic masticatory muscle activity.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Case-control studies show GERD-bruxism association (OR=6.87), though from limited research groups. One small RCT supports PPI treatment.

interventions.name: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy
interventions.description: Structured therapy addressing thoughts and behaviors that may contribute to bruxism.
interventions.detailedDescription: Three RCTs exist but GRADE evidence is extremely low for sleep bruxism specifically. One RCT showed EMG reduction at 6-month follow-up. Better evidence for awake bruxism. Consider if stress or anxiety are significant contributors.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Very limited RCT evidence for sleep bruxism. May help if stress/anxiety are major contributors.

interventions.name: Sleep Hygiene
interventions.description: Maintain consistent sleep schedule, dark room, cool temperature, and avoid screens before bed.
interventions.detailedDescription: While direct evidence for bruxism reduction is limited, good sleep hygiene reduces arousals that trigger grinding episodes. Key practices: consistent bedtime, no screens 1hr before bed, cool dark room (65-68¬∞F), no caffeine after noon.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Addresses arousal triggers indirectly. No direct RCT evidence for bruxism but foundational for sleep health.

interventions.name: Posture Check
interventions.description: Maintain good head and neck posture throughout the day. Poor posture can contribute to jaw tension.
interventions.detailedDescription: Forward head posture places strain on the jaw muscles. Regular posture checks during the day, ergonomic workstation setup, and stretching breaks can reduce this strain.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Theoretical benefit through reduced muscle strain. No direct bruxism research but low risk.

interventions.name: Magnesium Supplement
interventions.description: Magnesium may help with muscle relaxation. Consult your doctor before starting supplements.
interventions.detailedDescription: Only one small pilot study (n=18, no control group) exists. Theoretical mechanism via muscle relaxation. May help sleep quality generally. Not recommended as a primary bruxism treatment. Caution: can interact with antibiotics, muscle relaxants, and blood pressure medications. Do not exceed 350mg/day supplemental without medical supervision.
interventions.evidenceSummary: No RCT evidence for bruxism specifically. May support general sleep quality. Check for drug interactions; stay under 350mg/day supplemental.

interventions.name: Heat/Cold Therapy
interventions.description: Apply warm compress or ice pack to jaw muscles to relieve tension and reduce inflammation.
interventions.detailedDescription: Warm compresses before bed can relax jaw muscles. Ice packs help with acute pain or inflammation. Low-risk symptom management. Use 15-20 minutes at a time.
interventions.evidenceSummary: Symptom relief only; no evidence for reducing grinding. Very low risk and cost.
